items.title: Achieve single-slit and double-slit diffraction
items.body:
### Description

A recent paper (July 2024) from NVIDIA Research, 
https://research.nvidia.com/labs/rtr/publication/steinberg2024diffraction/steinberg2024_fsd_paper_lowres.pdf, 
demonstrated free-space diffraction, where rays bend around edges and corners of scene objects.

This was achieved with raytracing, not quantum mechanics probability wave theory.

Here's a video summary, 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jfVn2ABxTo&ab_channel=NVIDIADeveloper.

Can three.js reproduce this?

### Solution

Achieve single-slit and double-slit diffraction, and share it on https://threejs.org/examples.

### Alternatives

.

### Additional context

The implementation would require tracing rays from the light source, not the camera

items.title: Raycaster on Line should match line width in screen space units
items.body:
### Description

Since `Line` commonly uses `LineBasicMaterial`, I would have expected `Raycaster` to honor the `LineBasicMaterial.lineWidth`. It also seems the threshold is interpreted in world units, not screen space, going against the general intuition of `LineBasicMaterial`.

### Solution

* Replace the `threshold` with `material.lineWidth` in `Line.raycast`.
* Make it use screen space distances.
* Make `Raycaster.params.Line.threshold === 0` to mean that `lineWidth` and screen space distance is used.
* Do the corresponding thing for `Points`.
* Bonus: Make `Line` and `Points` compatible with `Mesh` by handling undefined material to mean it's invisible.

### Alternatives

There have been a few additions to the Line2 and LineSegments2 examples in recent years, but I'm wondering why that hasn't reached core.

* https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/11349
* https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/15356
* https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/24405

### Additional context

The `Raycaster` does not look much at materials when determining intersections, with few exceptions:

1. `Mesh` et al. will make no intersection if the material is undefined.
2. `Sprite` looks at `sizeAttenuation` and `rotation` (i.e. it assumes a `SpriteMaterial` is being used.)

Both `Line` and `Points` use thresholds that are static for the `Raycaster`, and don't care about materials. As with `lineWidth`, the `PointMaterial.size` would be useful to honor, though it would also have to take `sizeAttenuation` into account.

* Mesh: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/17abdb5e4b88368a6c1528743d014e641b32cf85/src/objects/Mesh.js#L156
* Sprite: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/17abdb5e4b88368a6c1528743d014e641b32cf85/src/objects/Sprite.js#L80-L86
* Line: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/17abdb5e4b88368a6c1528743d014e641b32cf85/src/objects/Line.js#L85
* Points: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/17abdb5e4b88368a6c1528743d014e641b32cf85/src/objects/Points.js#L46

### Description

WebXR session started flickering in left eye recently.
I'm using Oculus Q2, also reproduces on Q3 and event caught it on Apple Vision Pro a few times (but not that consistent).

items.title: Alias-like artefacts in WebGL2 fallback in r168
items.body:
### Description

In some very specific cases there is a significant difference in rendering between r167 and r168. Some alias-like (or pixelation) artefacts appear along the edge of objects.

The following four things make the difference show up:

- WebGL2 fallback (i.e. three.webgpu.js is used)
- high shininess (zero roughness, full metalness)
- high border curvature (object is flattened) 
- high contrast (light object, dark background, strong light)

I am not sure how to classify this issue: bug, side-effect or expected-behaviour.

When the contrast is not high (e.g. the light is weak), it is easier to see that r168 makes better shading of the interior areas, but the edges still appear pixelated.

The difference has been spotted while converting some r167 programs into r168. So far I have not found a solution, besides downgrading to r167.

### Reproduction steps

1. Open the live example in a non-WebGPU browser
2. Change the release number in line 5 - compare 168 against 167
3. optional step: compare r168/r167 when intensity is 1, not 10 (change in line 17)

### Code

```js
import * as THREE from "https://unpkg.com/three@0.168.0/build/three.webgpu.js";
:
var renderer = new THREE.WebGPURenderer( {antialias: true} );
: 
var light = new THREE.DirectionalLight( 'white', 10 );
:
var object = new THREE.Mesh(
   new THREE.TorusGeometry( 1, 0.4 ),
   new THREE.MeshPhysicalNodeMaterial( {
      roughness: 0,
      metalness: 1,
   } )
);	
object.scale.z = 0.05;
```

items.title: The new iPhone browser will have jagged edges
BatchedMesh does not accurately compute bounding box when instancing geometry
items.body:
### Description

There seems to be an obvious bug in `BatchedMesh#computeBoundingBox`. The routine `BatchedMesh#computeBoundingSphere` routine properly sets the for loop bounds to be 0 to `drawInfo.length`, but the `BatchedMesh#computeBoundingBox` routine sets the loop bounds to be 0 to `geometryCount`, which cuts the loop short if you have multiple instances of the same geometry.

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/src/objects/BatchedMesh.js#L308

The net result is you get an inaccurate bounding box if you instance the same geometry more than once in a batched mesh.

### Reproduction steps

1. Add several instances of the same geometry to a batched mesh, at different transforms
2. Compute the bounding box
3. Notice the box is wrong

### Code

No code or example, bug seems clear.

### Live example

No code or example, bug seems clear.

### Screenshots

### Version

r167

items.title: gltf-model loading speed optimization
glTF exported from OnShape with compression on fail to load
Visibility (Cull or hide) flags
items.body:
# Description

This is not a concept, it might be completely inappropriate, I didn't really thought through this one - this is just an idea.

## Culling

There are several factors telling if the object be rendered and taking into account for computations, currently the only thing I found is `visible`, it is useful but very restricted.

It would be nice to have known culling and hiding methods built-in into the library.

**Pros**

This is good to have it built-in

**Cons**

Of course, maintenance and extensibility. Not sure though as the most of hide/cull flags must be one-time implementation. I believe it will not require any changes once polished.

## Behavior

Beyond avoiding object rendering, it is very useful to know if the object can be considered as operational and "useful".

- scene-presence (if it is somewhere in the scene)
- culling (if it was culled (excluded from the rendering))

Another one is distance, though I'm not sure here at all.

### When useful

If an object that is being animated, when has been excluded from rendering, you probably want it to pause the animation while it's not rendered and then turn it on when it is.

---

This is just an idea, I may be completely wrong in all of this... _You know, sudden tonight motivation and ideas after a good nap..._

# Solution

## Culling

Add [enum flags](https://www.alanzucconi.com/2015/07/26/enum-flags-and-bitwise-operators/) property like `cullFlags` to have a range of possible culling methods while not facing any extra performance burden. However developer can decided what types of culling is the most appropriate per object.

It can be:
- Frustum culling
- Oclusion culling
- Hierarchical Z-Buffer culling
- VR oclusion culling

_I may be wrong here, there are very limited and contrary information in the internet (it may be just uncompleted), it didn't spend too much time investigating it_

### Occlusion culling

Talking specifically about occlusion culling, it will be possible as soon as the `GPURenderer` is there according a thread I'm too lazy to find <--...

## Extensibility

It could be solved by providing a new interface to `render` method or in the constructor of a `Renderer`. Might be something like `shouldCull` that would be called on each renderable object. Which, in theory, would allow extending the amount of flags by providing a custom _Filter_ callback.

Though it might not be needed just the same as for maintenance, if implemented, it might not require any further development. IMHO.

## Behavior

Add methods like `onExcluded` and `onIncluded` (the naming is exemplary) to tell the script if it should adjust its behavior mechanisms. They would fire once a state is recomputed.

Can't really tell the difference between firing before and after render.

Also, nice to have additional property for telling if the object is in the scene or not, which should probably trigger the methods as well.

# Alternatives

Add booleans properties instead of one with flags or reject this issue saying
> It could be done with a library instead, it should not belong to the library

I just don't actually know...

# Additional context

In the documentation, it should be said that extending the enum flags should be from the end or by creating a standalone property to avoid compatibility issues with future releases.

items.body:
### Description

I'm trying to use `Earcut` inside a Typescript project and I'm getting a type error.
The type declaration says that `Earcut.triangulate` returns `Triangle[]` but after looking through the source it appears to be returning `number[]`

### Reproduction steps

1. Update `package.json` to use `threeJS` r140 or higher.
2. Put the below code in your index file.
3. Open `node_modules/@types/three/src/extras/Earcut.d.ts` and you'll see the declaration for `triangulate` defines `Triangle[]` not `number[]`.

### Code

```js
import { Earcut } from "three/src/extras/Earcut";

const triangles = Earcut.triangulate([10, 0, 0, 50, 60, 60, 70, 10], [], 3);
console.log(triangles); // returns [1, 0, 3, 3, 2, 1]
console.log(typeof triangles[0]); // returns number
```

items.title: ViewportNode: Honor the renderer viewport
items.body: ### Description The above image is from the [webGPU MRT example](https://threejs.org/examples/webgpu_mrt.html), _modified_ by setting a custom renderer viewport. The original example uses this pattern: ```js const out = mix( output.renderOutput(), output, step( 0.2, viewportTopLeft.x ) ); ``` I have been able to honor the viewport by using this pattern: ```js const offset = Fn( () => { return viewportTopLeft.x.mul( viewportResolution.x ).div( 2 ).sub( viewport.x ).div( viewport.z ); // 2 is the DPR for my device } ); const out = mix( output.renderOutput(), output, step( 0.2, offset() ) ); ``` It is a red flag that it is necessary to inject the device DPR (2) into the formula. It is a warning that the units on the TSL functions are not correct. Some are scaled by DPR -- others are not... Or maybe the functions are fine, but the names can be improved. Also, `viewportTopLeft` is not the top-left of the viewport. It is the fragment coordinate normalized by some quantity -- likely by the width of the frame buffer. Perhaps the nomenclature can be improved. Something that implies: "Normalized fragment coordinate relative to the top-left of the viewport". ### Reproduction steps See above. ### Code See above. ### Live example n/a ### Screenshots _No response_ ### Version r168dev ### Device Desktop ### Browser Chrome ### OS MacOS

items.title: Renderer does not recover sometimes which switching between Android apps (Firefox)
items.body:
### Description

This issue has been happening for a very long time across multiple Firefox Android versions.

In general, if I'm viewing any web page in Firefox for Android with an active threejs renderer, if I switch to another app and do enough activity to put Firefox in a background state, and come back to the web page, the page is still loaded (it didn't refresh) but the canvas the threejs renderer was drawing to is fully transparent. It is basically "acting" like the gl context is lost, but if I inspect the gl instance it doesn't reflect this:

* gl.isContextLost() is false.
* No errors are being logged to the console.
* Even though renderer.render() is still being called consistently, gl.getError() is 0 (NO_ERROR)
* The scene still has all the children set up as expected. I have a very basic square plane geometry with a MeshBasicMaterial with a white color property that isn't displaying.
* I also have another geometry with custom shader with a texture map that has an ImageBitmap source. The ImageBitmap is still valid in memory. I tested that it is valid by manually binding it to the existing GL context:
  ```
  const texture = gl.createTexture()
  gl.bindTexture(gl.TEXTURE_2D, texture)
  gl.texImage2D(gl.TEXTURE_2D, 0, gl.RGBA, gl.RGBA, gl.UNSIGNED_BYTE, scene.children[0].material.uniforms.map.source.data)
  console.log(gl.getError()); // 0
  ```
* gl.getParameter(gl.ARRAY_BUFFER_BINDING) returns a WebGLBuffer object
* gl.getVertexAttrib(0, gl.VERTEX_ATTRIB_ARRAY_ENABLED) is null

My general expectation is that threejs should be able to automatically recover from Firefox "sleeping" the web page.

If I manually call `renderer.forceContextLoss()` then `render.forceContextRestore()`, it does start working again. But I'm trying to figure out how do programmatically identify what the actual issue is. It's not telling me that the context is lost when inspecting the API.

### Reproduction steps

1. Visit a page that is using threejs in Firefox for Android
2. Switch to another application, do enough activity in that application to cause Firefox for Android to start attempting to save resources?
3. Return to the webpage in Firefox for Android.


### Code

This isn't a specific problem to any threejs program, in general the renderer gets in a state where it is apparently still "working" but doesn't draw anything.

### Live example

https://threejs.org/docs/#api/en/materials/MeshBasicMaterial

149

Mobile

Firefox

items.title: WebXRDepthSensing can result in invalid projectionMatrix (`NaN` values)
items.body:
### Description

When using WebXR depth sensing, Three.js adjusts the `far` and `near` properties of the camera to match the `depthFar` and `depthNear` coming from the depth-sensing module. In the case of the Meta Quest 3, the `far` value becomes `Infinity`. As a result, the left, right, XR _and_ user cameras all end up with `NaN` values in their projection matrix as `Matrix4.makePerspective` does not support an infinite far plane.

Rendering during the immersive session still looks fine as the projection matrices provided by WebXR are used when rendering the left and right views ([WebXRManager.js#L752-L753](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/src/renderers/webxr/WebXRManager.js#L752-L753)). NaN values also show up in the Frustum, but somehow don't cause noticeable issues (perhaps nothing gets frustum culled?).

When exiting the immersive session, the scene is rendered with the user-camera, which now has `NaN` values in its projection matrix, resulting in the screen showing up empty (see screenshots).

The current depth sensing implementation assumes that Three.js supports a far value of `Infinity`. A proper solution would either be to support it (#11755) or handle occlusion differently (#28877). A crude workaround could be to fix/restore the projection matrix of the user-camera upon exiting the session (something I now do in some of my experiences).

### Reproduction steps

1. Open the [`webxr_xr_dragging`](https://threejs.org/examples/#webxr_xr_dragging) example on a Quest 3
2. Click on 'Start XR' 
3. Click on 'Stop XR' to exit
4. Notice the canvas being blank


### Code

```js
document.body.appendChild( XRButton.createButton( renderer, {
	'optionalFeatures': [ 'depth-sensing' ],
	'depthSensing': { 'usagePreference': [ 'gpu-optimized' ], 'dataFormatPreference': [] }
} ) );
```


### Live example

* [`webxr_xr_dragging`](https://threejs.org/examples/#webxr_xr_dragging) 



### Screenshots

| Before entering XR | After exiting XR |
|----------------|-------------|
| ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b7dfdd3e-3c33-4dd9-84fb-8d14b3f253dc) | ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dd78ab95-ef55-455d-a11a-e5e14b9b2341) |

items.title: [Sample] webgpu_performance_renderbundle sample could have more optimal usage of GPURenderBundles and GPUBindGroups
items.body:
### Description

[webgpu_performance_renderbundle](https://threejs.org/examples/?q=webgpu#webgpu_performance_renderbundle) shows the benefit render bundles, but instead of creating a single render bundle as done https://webgpu.github.io/webgpu-samples/?sample=renderBundles and encoding all draw commands, a render bundle per object is created. This seems unnecessary.

### Solution

I would propose the sample builds a single GPURenderBundle instance, encoding all 4000 draws, rather than building 4000 GPURenderBundle instances and potentially allowing the browser implementation to coalesce the render bundle draws.

Additionally, as shown in https://webgpu.github.io/webgpu-samples/?sample=animometer, it is not necessary to create 4000 GPUBindGroup instances and 4000 GPUBuffer instances. 

Instead, 1 GPUBuffer and 1 GPUBindGroup can be created. The GPUBindGroup's layout would get created with `hasDynamicOffset: true` and then the offset into the larger GPUBuffer can be passed to `setBindGroup` to draw object N of 4000.

This also reduces the number of GPUQueue.writeBuffer calls from 4000 to 1 per frame, a significant performance savings.

### Alternatives

A browser implementation could internally optimize these calls, but this requires some level of caching which may or may not be necessary depending on workload and is difficult to predict. 

The web engine / website has a bit more insight into how a GPUBuffer will be used and it is more optimal to perform the coalescing at that level.

### Additional context

See https://webgpu.github.io/webgpu-samples/?sample=animometer for optimal usage of GPURenderBundles with GPUBindGroup and GPUBindGroupLayout instances

items.title: Nodes: SelectionPassNode
Set An Object3D Global Matrix Manually
items.body:
### Description

Currently my understanding is that you cannot set the global matrix of an object. The matrix is read from the position, rotation, and scale. You can apply a matrix transform, but you cannot set the global matrix manually. 

### Solution

I would like the ability to set the matrix manually. AKA, switch the matrix from the driven property of the object to the driving property, perhaps through a flag. This would be advantageous for users who are not working with position and rotation directly but just with matrix operations. 

### Alternatives

Another approach would be to allow manual setting of the matrix whenever the `matrixAutoUpdate` flag is false. 

### Additional context

This would be awesome for developers who want their code to match closely with matrix transformation math prominent in certain industries like robotics.

items.title: TSL transpiler lessThan()
items.body:
### Description

Transpiling a GLSL code containing `lessThan()` doesn't produce a working TSL version.
We don't see `lessThan()` a lot, but it happens.

### Reproduction steps

3. Try the result


### Code

The following GLSL

```glsl
s = vec4(lessThan(p, vec4(0.0)));
```

produces the following TSL

```js
import { /* ... */ lessThan, /* ... */ } from 'three/tsl';

// ...
s.assign( vec4( lessThan( p, vec4( 0.0 ) ) ) );

items.title: import from `three/webgpu` incompatible with UltraHDRLoader
items.body:
### Description

This is a larger problem but i take the UltraHDLoader case.

UltraHDLoader dependencies are from `three` 
In r167 I replaced all my import from `three` to `three/webgpu` accessible build via the package.json
So i get logically `WARNING: Multiple instances of Three.js being imported.`.

This problem is likely to happen on other class and the 'easy' solution under is not very elegant.

### Reproduction steps

1. import the UltraHDLoader in a project importing files from `three/webgpu`

### Code

threejs `package.json` relevant part : 
```
  "type": "module",
  "main": "./build/three.cjs",
  "module": "./build/three.module.js",
  "exports": {
    ".": {
      "import": "./build/three.module.js",
      "require": "./build/three.cjs"
    },
    "./examples/fonts/*": "./examples/fonts/*",
    "./examples/jsm/*": "./examples/jsm/*",
    "./addons": "./examples/jsm/Addons.js",
    "./addons/*": "./examples/jsm/*",
    "./src/*": "./src/*",
    "./webgpu": "./build/three.webgpu.js",
    "./tsl": "./build/three.webgpu.js"
  },
```

easy fix for this case, i duplicate the class and changed the import.. : 
```
import {
	ClampToEdgeWrapping,

	FileLoader,
	HalfFloatType,
	LinearFilter,
	LinearMipMapLinearFilter,

[Migration-Guide](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/wiki/Migration-Guide)

> The build files build/three.js and build/three.min.js have been removed. Please use ES Modules or alternatives: https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#manual/en/introduction/Installation

A change of the code to use three.js as module is possible, but does NOT always work.

One major problem:
Many people are using examples and are operating with local code, without any web server.
Local code will not work with modules.

### Reproduction steps

1. Take the example: [Fluid](https://codepen.io/kynd/pen/jOXZXWB)
2. Copy the code to a local folder
3. Execute the HTML file by double click
4. Modify the code to use Three.js as module
5. Execute the HTML file by double click


### Code

```js
<script language="javascript" type="text/javascript" src="https://threejs.org/build/three.js"></script>
```

items.title: Mesh: allow caller to specify which geometry to raycast and ignore material visibility
items.body:
### Description

Currently, calling `Mesh.raycast()` will use the `.geometry` of the mesh for raycasting purposes. However, in some cases it might be useful to specify another geometry (for example, a simplified convex hull geometry).

Currently, the only way to do that is if the simplified geometry is its own mesh in the scene graph (as a child of the renderable mesh). The renderable mesh would then override `raycast()` to raycast the simplified mesh instead.

 However, since the simplified mesh is not renderable, adding it to the scene graph is superfluous and might lead to performance overhead (even if the mesh is not `visible`).


### Solution

A possible solution would be to extract the mesh raycasting logic in a helper (that `Mesh` would use). Something like:

```js
MeshRaycaster.raycast(geometry, matrixWorld, raycaster, intersectList);
``` 
This way, any object would be able to perform mesh intersection tests without having a geometry itself, or maybe if it has to use a different geometry than the renderable one.

An additional benefit is that currently the implementation of `raycast()` by the mesh checks if the material is visible, and does not perform the raycast if the material is not visible. The `MeshRaycaster` helper does not care about the material, so this logic could be circumvented for geometries used purely for raycasting.

### Alternatives

Another possibility would be to add options to `Mesh.raycast()`, to allow for overriding the geometry used:

```js
// In a subclass of Mesh:
raycast(raycaster, intersectList) {
    super.raycast(raycaster, intersectList, { geometry: myCustomColliderGeometry, checkMaterial: false });
}
```

However this would change the API (although not a breaking change), so it is less elegant than the helper solution.

### Additional context

When raycasting against complex geometries, we might want a simplified geometry for raycasting purposes.

For example, the Unity3D game engine distinguish between the *collider* component of the GameObject (which can have its own mesh) and the renderable mesh.

items.body:
### Description

Add transformation and cloning functions for the Shape class hierarchy, extending to paths, curves ect. Where transformation on the shape propagates down through all of the components that make it up.

### Solution

Provide Deep transform and clone functions to essentially apply transformation (rotation, translation, and potentially mirroring) and a clone function to duplicate it for transformation. This would be applied to all the different curves, curvepath, path, shape.

### Alternatives

Use instanced mesh style 4x4 transformation matrix to apply to the shape.

### Additional context

Would like to transform the shape before creating a shape buffer geometry or extruded geometry for further manipulation in other libraries. And/or creating a base shape to merge with another shape. Transforming at this level would make it more efficient than having to create all the way to the mesh and transforming it there.

items.title: Increase the current limit for attributes from 8 to 12 or 16
items.body:
### Description

At the moment I can create a maximum of 8 attributes for custom buffer geometries in the node system. As far as I know, at least 16 are possible for webgl and webgpu.

So this falls into the suggestion area.

I currently use 7 attributes, but could need 2 more, which would bring me to 9, so one more attribute than possible. This is nothing urgent and nothing critical because it's not an error.

However, more than 8 attributes are desirable because I can use attributes to implement advanced morphing techniques and thus save massive amounts of computing effort in the shader.


### Solution

The solution is to increase the limit for attributes from 8 to 16.


### Alternatives

The alternative is that I carry out calculations on the shader side. Of course that works. However, if I can use target attributes calculated once, it is more efficient than over 100 lines of code in the shader that are run through at every interval.

### Additional context

For you as developers so that you can also see a little of what is possible with WebGPU and the node system:

![mars65k](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4ed083a5-6cca-4eb5-b74c-3c49de5b69fe)

![mars65k2](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5044b2b2-b8f5-4dcc-9300-fb3319c4a810)

![131k_3](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4f405ac7-78c6-4f0b-9b3d-0e955775d848)

I still have some work to do but the most difficult part is over.
Let's see if I can put it online this year.

items.title: examples/webgpu_morphtargets_face.html uses rgba32-float filtering textures without checking feature
items.body:
### Description

Apologies in advance if bug reports are not appropriate for samples.

Float32 filtering is an optional feature in WebGPU: https://www.w3.org/TR/webgpu/#float32-filterable and it is not available on all devices, specifically most iPhones which include a preview for WebGPU support in the iOS 18 developer betas.

It appears the webgpu - morph targets - face example (https://threejs.org/examples/?q=webgpu#webgpu_morphtargets_face) does not fall back to rgba16float textures when the feature is not supported

### Reproduction steps

1. Enable WebGPU on iOS 18 beta via Settings.app -> Apps -> Safari -> Advanced -> Feature Flags -> WebGPU
2. Open https://threejs.org/examples/?q=webgpu#webgpu_morphtargets_face
3. If the device is an iPhone 15 Pro or recent iPad, any one which where -[MTLDevice supports32BitFloatFiltering] returns true, the sample loads correctly
4. If the device is an iPhone 15 (non-Pro) or earlier, any non-M Apple8 device or earlier from https://developer.apple.com/metal/Metal-Feature-Set-Tables.pdf the sample is empty

items.title: Json Parsing changes for Shape/Path/Curves subclasses' CurrentPoint
items.body:
### Description

fromJson/toJson in Path.js has currentPoint being interpreted from Vector2's fromArray, which doesn't really follow how currentPoint is actually defined if replicating Vector2 class itself. Where it is an object with x and y property.
Currently creating data objects in C# backend in which currentPoints was setup like vector2. People who want to create their own json format of the object will have their data structure slightly different.

### Solution

In the inheritance chain from Curve.js for classes that are taking in arrays to turn into Vector2 in the toJson and fromJson methods and change them to assume that the json is taken in as a vector object with property x, y instead of being a length 2 vector.

### Alternatives

Keep current convention and hopefully an explanation for why it's being read as an array instead.

### Additional context

I get that it is a closed loop with toJson and fromJson, but in some cases people need to optimize for performance and create all the data objects server side, which is serialized to JSON over api requests.

If this change is encouraged, I can make the changes for a PR.

### Description

I've been receiving a warning concerning optimization of the canvas for readback operations while GLTFExporter's parse method is running. According to the warning, a `getContext` call should contain a `willReadFrequently` context attribute set true. Details are [here](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/canvas.html#concept-canvas-will-read-frequently)

It seems like GLTFExporter's source code is missing any context attributes with `getContext` calls

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/examples/jsm/exporters/GLTFExporter.js#L1276

### Solution

If there are no obstacles, let's add `willReadFrequently` context attributes set true for every `getContext` call inside GLTFExporter's source code

items.title: Inconsistency in setColorAt() Method Behavior Between BatchedMesh and InstancedMesh
items.body:
### Description

Hello,

I have noticed some inconsistencies in the behavior of the `setColorAt()` method between the `BatchedMesh` and `InstancedMesh` classes, and I believe these may be indicative of bugs. Here are the main differences:

When calling the `setColorAt()` method on an `InstancedMesh`, all instances other than the one with the newly set color turn black. However, when using the `setColorAt()` method on a `BatchedMesh`, the colors of the other instances do not change. I believe this behavior in `InstancedMesh` might be a bug.

In `BatchedMesh`, the `needsUpdate` flag is set to true internally by the `setColorAt()` method. In contrast, for `InstancedMesh`, the caller must manually set `needsUpdate` externally, and this is also true for other methods like `setMatrixAt()` and `setMorphAt()`. This discrepancy can be confusing for users as one class requires external setting of `needsUpdate`, while the other does not.

### Solution

1. Set the initial value for the Color array of `InstancedMesh`
2. The `needsUpdate` properties of both classes are changed to be set inside the class

### Alternatives

none

### Additional context

_No response_

items.title: Clear only certain stencil bits
items.body:
### Description

Tangentially related to #26737

When using stencil to display something per-object like in https://threejs.org/examples/webgl_clipping_stencil.html, one wants to clear the stencil after the object is done:

```js
					po.onAfterRender = function ( renderer ) {

						renderer.clearStencil();

					};
```

In real application only certain bits can be used for the effect in question which other bits are used for something else and should be left untouched. For this one would like to set the stencil mask before clearing it.


### Solution

At the moment color and alpha can be controlled by calls `setClearColor` and `setClearAlpha`. I suggeest adding `setClearStencil` and `setClearStencilMask` to control stencil buffer value and mask used on the clear.


### Alternatives

One can clear the stencil bit by rendering a fullscreen quad with carefully crafted stencil settings of the material. This cannot be used in `onAfterRender` thought, instead one needs to play with render order of the quad and the effect object to make sure the are rendered after each other.

### Additional context

I can try preparing a PR if the functionality looks acceptable.

items.title: WebGPURenderer: `MeshNormalMaterial` should not be tone mapped
items.body:
### Description

__WebGLRenderer__:

`MeshNormalMaterial` inherits the `.toneMapped` property as `true`, but the material omits the tone mapping shader chunks, so the material is never tone mapped.

This is the correct behavior. We never want the material to be tone mapped.

__WebGPURenderer__:

`MeshNormalMaterial` responds to tone mapping. It should not. This needs to be fixed.

Note: There are other problems with `MeshNormalMaterial` that cause the material to be washed out when rendered with `WebGPURenderer`. That will be addressed in a separate PR after this issue is resolved.

When working at the environment map, I've noticed two issues:

items.title: WebGPURenderer: `CubeRenderTarget.fromEquirectangularTexture()` does not work with sRGB input.
items.body:
### Description

`WebGPURenderer` should be able to automatically convert equirectangular texture to the cube map format. I've tried to implement auto-conversion for `envMap` in `BasicEnvironmentNode` but then encountered an issue.

`CubeRenderTarget.fromEquirectangularTexture()` (which internally uses `CubeCamera.update()`) only works if the input is `linear-srgb`. If it is `srgb` which is more or less always true for non HDR textures, the rendering fails with the following WebGPU warnings:
```
Texture view array layer range (baseArrayLayer: 1, arrayLayerCount: 1) exceeds the texture's array layer count (1).
 - While validating [TextureViewDescriptor] against [Texture (unlabeled 2734x1288 px, TextureFormat::RGBA16Float)].
 - While calling [Texture (unlabeled 2734x1288 px, TextureFormat::RGBA16Float)].CreateView([TextureViewDescriptor]).

_display/:1 [Invalid TextureView] is invalid.
 - While validating colorAttachments[0].
 - While encoding [CommandEncoder "renderContext_2"].BeginRenderPass([null]).

_display/:1 [Invalid CommandBuffer from CommandEncoder "renderContext_2"] is invalid.
 - While calling [Queue].Submit([[Invalid CommandBuffer from CommandEncoder "renderContext_2"]])
```
The renderer logs this for the `baseArrayLayer` 1-5 which means for the cube sides 1-5. The first one seems to render as expected.

### Reproduction steps

1. Go to https://jsfiddle.net/hvoju7bw/1/.
2. Check browser console.



### Code

```js
const renderer = new THREE.WebGPURenderer();
renderer.setPixelRatio(window.devicePixelRatio);
renderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
document.body.appendChild(renderer.domElement);

await renderer.init();

const loader = new THREE.TextureLoader();

const texture = await loader.loadAsync('https://threejs.org/examples/textures/2294472375_24a3b8ef46_o.jpg');
texture.mapping = THREE.EquirectangularReflectionMapping;
texture.colorSpace = THREE.SRGBColorSpace;

const renderTarget = new CubeRenderTarget(texture.image.height);
renderTarget.fromEquirectangularTexture(renderer, texture);
```
